The problem is the intercept velocity. The Hermes cannot enter Mars orbit, or they'll never have enough fuel to make it home. The MAV is only designed to get to Low Mars Orbit. So in order for Mark to escape Mars' gravity entirely and intercept the Hermes...
He needs to be going fast.
Which means we need to make the MAV lighter. A lot lighter. Five-thousand kilograms lighter.
You can do that?
Bruce gives him a look that says, well, that depends on y definition of "do that," Vincent. He begins to deconstruc scale model of the MAV:
There were some gimmes right off the bat. The design presumes 500 kilograms of Martian soil and samples. Obviously, we won't do that.
There's just one passenger instead of six. With suits and gear, that saves another 500. Then we ditch the life support. We don't need it. We'll have Watney use his EVA suit for the whole trip.
How will he use the controls?
He won't. Martinez will pilot the MAV remotely from the Hermes.
We've never had a manned ship controlled remotely before. (off Mitch's look) But... I'm excited for the opportunities that affords.
If we go remote, we can lose the control panels. Then we dump the secondary and tertiary comm systems.
You're going to have a remote controlled ascent with no backup comms?
He's not even to the bad stuff yet, Vincent.
Really?
You better skip to the bad stuff.
We have to remove the nose airlock, the windows, and Hull Panel 19.
(what?) You're taking the front of the ship off?
Sure. The nose airlock alone is 400 kilograms.
You're going to launch a man into space with a giant hole in the front of the ship?
Well... no. We're gonna have him cover it with Hab canvas.
Vincent puts his head in his hands.

The hull's mostly there to keep the air in. Mars' atmosphere is so thin you don't need a lot of streamlining. By the time the ship's going fast enough for air resistance to matter, it'll be high enough that there's practically no air.
You're sending him to space under a tarp.
Yes. Can I go on?
I'm not really sure I want you to, but okay.
Mindy reads Mark's response while the group awaits. Mitch looks on from his station.
Mark says... "Are you f-word-ing kidding me?"
Do you think he meant it like...
"Are you kidding me?" Or more...
"Are you kidding me?"
(doesn't want to hurt
It's... possible he meant it the first way?
Mark stares at the camera with a look that says, "Oh jesu these JPL guys are gonna get me killed."

I know what they're doing. I know what they're doing. They keep repeating "accelerate faster than any man in the history of space travel" like this is a good thing, like this'll distract me from how insane their plan is. Oh really? I get to be the fastest man in the history of space travel? You're launching me into space in a convertible. No no, it's worse, because I don't have any controls. You're launching me into space in a tin can. And, by the way, physicists don't even use words like "fast" when describing acceleration, so they're only doing it in hopes I won't raise any objections because I like the way "fastest man in the history of space travel" sounds. Well, you know what?
(thinks about it) I do like it. I do like the way it sounds.
Okay, fine. Let's do this.
MUSIC UP: "Waterloo" by ABBA begins to play...
Mark stands at the base of the MAV. He holds a large wren in his hand, almost like a weapon.
As Mark stares up at the MAV with a gleam in his eyes...
"My my at Waterloo Napoleon did surrender..."
Mark tears the acceleration chairs out of the cockpit.
WHUMP. One after another, the acceleration chairs hit the dirt in a pile. WHUMP.
Mark tears out the control panels. He's having fun.
WHUMP. The controls hit the dirt. The pile is growing.
MUSIC UP: "Waterloo" by ABBA begins to play...
Martinez runs through a flight simulation at his station. It's not going well. "Collision with Terrain" blinks in angry red letters on his screen.
And... you killed him.
Lewis shrugs. The taskmaster.
Try it again.
Martinez reboots the simulator... 92.
Mark waits in the airlock with a mess of stripped equipme
The outside of the MAV now looks like the set of Sanford Son. Mark wrenches one of the MAV's hull panels free.
UP ABOVE: The nose airlock breaks free, and tumbles down towards camera, BLACKING OUT FRAME.
FROM BLACK, we FIND MARK. He's sitting on a hill slope, surveying his handiwork.
The MAV has been TRANSFORMED. The whole front has been to off. Hab canvas now covers it. Equipment litters the area all around us. Junkyard on Mars.
"Finally facing my Waterloo..."
Mark just sits. Exhausted.
The music FADES.
The Hermes halts rotation as it approaches Mars.
Here's the plan...
The whole crew is present for the state of the union.

Martinez will fly the MAV. Johanssen will sysop the ascent. Beck and Vogel, I want you in Airlock 2 with the outer door open before the MAV even launches. Once we reach intercept, it'll be Beck's job to get Watney.
He might be in bad shape. The stripped down MAV will get up to 12 g's during the launch. He could be knocked unconscious and may have internal bleeding.
Well, then it's a good thing you're our doctor. What's the intercept plan?
We finished attaching the tethers into one long line. It's 214 meters long. I'll have the MMU, so moving around should be easy.
How fast a relative velocity can you handle?
Once I get to Mark? I can grab the MAV at 5 meters per second. 10 is like jumping onto a moving train. Any more than that and I might miss.
We've got some leeway. The launch will be 52 minutes before the intercept and it takes 12 minutes. As soon as Mark's engine cuts out we'll know our intercept point and velocity.
Good. And 214 meters isn't a hard limit, per se.
Yes. It is.
I take off the tether, I could get way out to --
Not an option. Vogel, you're Beck's backup. All goes well, you're pulling them back aboard with the tether. If things go wrong, you're going out after them.
Ja.
All right. Let's go get our boy.
Mark sits inside the makeshift pressurized tent. He tears open his last remaining ration pack:
"Goodbye, Mars"
He eats in silence.

It's a mob scene at NASA. Networks from all across the gl have sent teams to cover the event. Campers, crews, and chaos all around as everyone fights for real estate in th biggest story of the century.
New-Years-Eve-Level crowds gather in Times Square. On the Jumbotron, news reports announce the "Watney Rescue."
Teddy, Vincent, and Annie watch from an observation area.
If something goes wrong, what can Mission Control do?

Not a damned thing. (off her look) It's all happening twelve light-minutes away. That means it takes twenty-four minutes for them to get the answer to any question they ask. The whole launch is twelve minutes long. They're on their own.
Not that we have a choice, but... are we sure we want to be broadcasting this to the world? I mean, if something goes
(cutting her off) Yes.
We want to be broadcasting this.
Mitch takes his position as Johanssen's VOICE rings out:
Fuel Pressure green.
Crowds watch the screens in Beijing as Johanssen's voice
Engine alignment perfect...
The cold is not keeping the crowds from watching the scre in the Palace Square.
Communications five by five...
Lewis nods. She's been waiting for this moment for some time. Keys the console --
About two minutes, Watney. How you doing down there?
Mark tries to keep his emotions under control as he waits the cockpit...
It's good to hear your voice, Commander. I'm eager to get up to you.
He fails. His voice breaks.
Thank you for coming back for me.
We're on the case. Remember, you'll be pulling some pretty heavy G's. It's okay to pass out. You're in Martinez' hands.
Tell that asshole no barrel-rolls.
Copy that, MAV. CAPCOM...
CLOSE ON JOHANSSEN, at her station.
Go.
Remote Command...
CLOSE ON MARTINEZ, grinning in anticipation.
Go.
Recovery...
CLOSE ON BECK as he floats in the open airlock. Beneath h the Red Planet blazes in all its brilliance.
Go.
Secondary recovery...
CLOSE ON VOGEL, clamped to the floor behind Beck.
Go.
Pilot...
And finally...
CLOSE ON MARK WATNEY, in his EVA suit, strapped into his acceleration seat.
ALL AROUND THE WORLD -- the CROWDS ERUPT IN CHEERS as the hear Mark's voice.
Mission control, this is Hermes actual. We are go for launch, and will proceed on schedule. 10 seconds to launch... mark.
Main engines start.
8... 7... mooring clamps released...
About five seconds, Watney. Hang on.
Mark tenses in anticipation.
See you in a few, Commander.
Mark is SLAMMED back into his acceleration couch --
SFX: the MAV launches upward with incredible force. And y as discussed, in the history of space travel, no manned s has ever accelerated with more force.
Mark can't even GASP -- the wind knocked out of him -- He struggles to remain conscious as the ship shakes VIOLENTL
MARK'S POV: staring forward, at the HAB CANVAS (which now patches where the nosecone used to be.)
As the ship accelerates, the canvas begins to RIP -- 98.
Velocity 741 meters per second. Altitude 1350 meters...
That's too low --
I know. It's fighting me --
Velocity 850, altitude 1843 --
Watney? Watney, do you read? Can you report?
But Mark's barely conscious -- his eyes drifting from terrified to serene as he fades --
HIS POV -- the canvas RIPS FREE....
Revealing the RED ATMOSPHERE of Mars. And as it thins -- we rocket towards the heavens -- the red gives way to the black...
And the last thing Mark sees before he drops unconscious
Are the STARS.
He's well below target altitude.
How far below?
Working on it -- Main shutdown in 3... 2... 1... Shutdown.
Back to automatic guidance. Confirm shutdown.
Watney? Do you read?
He's probably passed out. He pulled 12 G's on the ascent. Give him a few minutes.
Copy.
I have interval pings. Intercept velocity will be 11 meters per second...
I can make that work.
Distance at intercept will be --
We'll be 68 kilometers apart.
Did she say 68 kilometers? Kilometers?
Oh my god...
Keep it together. Work the problem. Martinez, do we have any juice in the
Negative, Commander. They ditched the OMS system to make launch weight.
Then we have to go him. Johanssen, time to intercept?
39 minutes, 12 seconds --
What if we point our attitude thrusters all the same direction?
Depends on how much fuel we want to save for attitude adjustments on the trip home.
How much do you need?
I could get by with maybe 20 percent of what's left.
(already working it) Use 75.5 percent of remaining attitude adjust fuel. That'll bring the intercept range to zero.
Do it.
Hang on -- that gets the range to zero, but the intercept velocity will be 42 meters per second --
Then we have 39 minutes to figure out how to slow down. Martinez, burn the jets.
WHOOSH. The attitude thrusters FIRE. The Hermes changes
CLOSE ON MARK as his eyelids flutter. He winces in pain a he slowly regains consciousness.
BENEATH HIM -- the orbiting MAV offers an unobstructed vi of Mars. The great red planet's horizon stretches out forever as the wispy atmosphere gives it a fuzzy edge.
It's breathtaking. Awe-inspiring.
Mark holds up his middle finger. Fuck you, Mars.
MAV to Hermes --
Watney?!
Affirmative, Commander.
What's your status?
My chest hurts. I think I broke some ribs.
How are you?
We're working on getting you. There was a complication during launch.
Yeah. The canvas didn't hold...
I think it ripped early in the ascent.
That's consistent with what we saw.
How bad is it, Commander?
We've corrected the intercept range, but we've got a problem with the intercept velocity.
How big a problem?
42 meters per second.
We're CLOSE ON MARK as that news lands.
Well. Shit.
Everyone struggles to find a solution. Mark's voice interrupts the silence:
Commander? 102.
Go ahead, Mark.

I could find something sharp in here and poke a hole in the glove of my EVA suit. I could use the escaping air as a thruster and fly my way to you. Since the source is on my arm, I could direct it pretty easy.
I can't see you having any control if you did that. You'd be eyeballing the intercept and using a thrust vector you can barely control.
Those are very good points. But.
I would get to fly around like Iron Man.
We should have left him on Mars.
Iron Man, Commander. Iron Man.
Lewis rubs her face. Thinks. Hmm...
Maybe it's not the worst idea.
No, it actually is. The worst idea. Ever.
Not his part. But using atmosphere as thrust... (springs into action) Martinez, get Vogel's station up and running...
It's up. What do you need?
I need to know what happens if we blow the VAL.
Both Martinez and Johanssen straighten up. What?
You want to open the Vehicular Airlock?
It would give us a good kick.
Yeah. And it might blow the nose of the ship off in the process.
And... all the air would leave. And we need air. To not die.
We'll seal the bridge and reactor room. We let everywhere else go vacuo.
But we'd still have the same problem as Watney. We can't direct the thrust.
We don't have to. The VAL is in the nose. We just point the ship at Mark.
(reading the numbers) A breach at the VAL would decelerate us 29 meters per second.
Which gives us a relative velocity of 13 meters per second.
Beck -- you hearing this?
How do we open the airlock doors? There's no way to open them remotely, and if anyone's nearby when it blows...
Right... right...
Vogel?
Go ahead, Commander.
Take your suit off.
I need you to come back in and make a bomb.
Did you say "bomb?" You guys are making a bomb without me?
Um... Again, please, Commander.
You're the chemist. Can you make a bomb with what we've got on board?
Probably. But... I feel obliged to mention that setting off an explosive device on a spacecraft is a terrible, terrible idea.
Copy that. Can you do it?
Ja.
Lewis' voice rings out through the room:
Houston, be advised: we are going to deliberately breach the VAL to produce thrust.
CHAOS erupts at Mission Control. WHAT DID SHE JUST SAY? 105.
Beck -- leave your suit on. Meet Johanssen at Airlock 1. We'll open the outer door. I need you to place the charge on the inner door...
...and climb back to Airlock 2 along the hull.
Copy. On my way.
Mark RIPS free a jagged edge of metal scrap from what use be the console.
Commander, I can't let you guys do this. I'm ready to puncture the suit. Let's go with the Iron Man plan.
Absolutely not.
The thing is, I'm selfish. And I want the memorials back home to be just me. I don't want the rest of you losers in them.
Commander... call it off.
Oh. Okay. Well, if you want us to call it off, then I guess we have to oh wait... wait a minute. Yep. I'm looking at my shoulder patch and it turns out I'm Commander. So shut up.
Smart ass.
Vogel works fast. He pours SUGAR into a strong glass beak Drills a hole in the stopper as Johanssen enters --
Bomb?
Bomb. In a pure oxygen environment, 16.7 million Joules will be released for every kilogram of sugar used. Eight times more powerful than a stick of dynamite.
He pours LIQUID OXYGEN into the beaker.
How do we activate it?
Vogel strips electrical wires, threads them into the stop
Can you run this to one of our lighting panels?
Johanssen grins.
Beck (in his spacesuit) enters the Vehicular Airlock as Johanssen is ripping wires out of the lighting panel and threading them into the bomb.
Make sure you're not still here when this goes off.
He takes the bomb from her.
They share a look.
Be careful. Out in space.
Johanssen kisses his face plate.
Don't tell anyone I did that.
Beck smiles. Closes the (inner) Airlock door behind her. 107.
As the OUTER DOOR opens, revealing SPACE, Beck finishes securing the improvised bomb to the inner door.
Bomb is set. On my way.
As Johanssen races back to her post, Martinez works quick at his station.
Guys, I'm running the numbers -- even with optimal VAL blow, we're gonna be off on our angle.
What's the new intercept distance?
Johanssen.
260 meters. Approximate.
That's too far...
She thinks for a moment. Then she races off the flight de
Commander?
Beck climbs out of Airlock 1, and makes his way along the hull of Hermes, using the handholds. We FOLLOW HIM as he traverses the ship, and as he makes his way into Airlock
...he finds LEWIS, fully suited up, waiting for him.
The intercept distance is gonna be too far. I'm going untethered.
Commander, I can do this --
It's not a debate, Beck. I'm not risking another crew member.
Beck sees there's no arguing with her.
Johanssen, time to VAL blow?
15 seconds...
We sure know how to cut it close.
Vogel rushes into the flight deck.
10 seconds...
Strap in.
They tighten the restraints on their chairs.
Brace for deceleration.
2... 1... Activating Panel 41.
She presses ENTER.
We're CLOSE ON THE BOMB as the current hits it...
KA-BOOOM! The EXPLOSION RIPS THE AIRLOCK DOOR TO SHREDS -
As the Hermes decelerates, Lewis and Beck are SLAMMED up against the wall --
Martinez, Vogel, and Johanssen endure the deceleration in their chairs. After four seconds, the ship stabilizes --
Bridge seal holding.
Damage?
Worry about that later... What's our relative velocity?
12 meters per second.
Copy.
And with that, Commander Lewis places her feet against th back wall for leverage...
What's our intercept range?
Johanssen stares at the calculations. That can't be right
312 meters.
Mark hears the news. Oh SHIT.
You said 312? Great. I'll wave at you guys as I go by.
I have visual on the MAV --
Lewis sails clear of the ship, controlling her movements her MMU. We SPOT the rotating MAV way off in the distance
Mark -- you're still WAY TOO FAR -- I'm not gonna make it --
Mark hears the news. Steels himself.
Commander. Seriously.
I got this.
Mark unclips his harness. Slams his makeshift knife into suit. WHOOSH -- the air shoots out through the puncture -
And we're OUTSIDE THE MAV -- as it tumbles away from us -
Mark Watney soars out of the ship.
(having the time of his
I have visual on the Commander.
AHEAD IN THE DISTANCE -- there's Lewis. Mark tries to adj course as they rocket towards each other.
Johanssen -- what's my relative velocity to Mark?
And as our SCORE begins to BUILD...
ANGLE JOHANSSEN -- knuckles white as she types --
5.2 meters per second...
ANGLE MARTINEZ -- on the edge of his seat --
Copy. Adjusting course --
ANGLE VOGEL -- heart in his throat --
3.1 meters per second...
ANGLE BECK -- watching the two figures rocket towards eac other below --
Distance to target -- 24 meters -- 111.
ANGLE LEWIS -- as she counter-thrusts, fires her MMU. Try to slow as Mark approaches --
11 meters to target...
And finally...
ANGLE MARK. As he cuts through space. Free as the proverbial bird. The Red Planet silhouetted behind him as leaves it behind, once and for all.
As the score SWELLS to CRESCENDO, these two astronauts so towards one another, arms outstretched...
6 meters to target...

head_text.subj: JUST AS THEY REACH EACH OTHER --

text: Contact.
Mark and Lewis float together, holding tight to one anoth
CLOSE ON MARK. As he stares at Lewis. The first human he has seen in ages. He smiles.
You have terrible taste in music.
Everyone leaps up as Lewis' voice rings out through missi
I got him.
They ERUPT into CHEERS --
-- and the CHEERS explode through RUSSIA... 112.
...and NEW YORK as news reports break the story of Mark's rescue on the big screens.
...and CHINA...
LEWIS guides MARK towards the airlock with her MMU.
Beck, prep the sick bay. We're bringing him to you. Everyone else, meet me in Airlock Two.

MARTINEZ, JOHANSSEN, and VOGEL race down from the bridge meet them. They're not in suits -- they have to wait for outer airlock to close. THROUGH THE OBSERVATION WINDOWS: they see Lewis and Mark touch down in the airlock.
The outer airlock closes -- WHOOSH -- Mark collapses, exhausted. The inner airlock opens. Martinez, Johanssen, and Vogel race into the room, grab Mark. Supporting him. Holding him.
Hi guys.
Everyone fighting back tears.
Oh, hey Mark. Haven't seen you in a while.
Yeah. What've you been up to?
Oh. You know. Same old, same old.
Click. They help him with his helmet. As they pull it off everyone is suddenly taken aback. Oh my god...
You smell horrible.
I haven't showered in a year and a half. Cut me some slack.
Johanssen's eyes are watering. Good lord, he smells bad.
You don't know what you're asking us here.
Yeah, captain, we may need to put him back.
I missed you guys.
They hold each another.
Home. It's never looked more warm and welcoming.
A man sits by himself on a bench.
ANGLE to reveal it's MARK WATNEY. Basking in the warmth o beautiful day.
The young, fresh-faced recruits in NASA's Astronaut Candi Program are abuzz as Mark enters the room. The students nudge each other -- Look, there he is.
By the time Mark reaches the lectern at the front, he has full attention of the class.
Welcome to the Astronaut Candidate Program. Pay attention. This could save your life.
Trust me, I know what I'm talking about.
The class laughs.

Okay, let's see if I can get some of your questions out of the way up front. Yes, I did, indeed, survive on a deserted planet by farming in my own shit. It was even more disgusting than it sounds. Let's never speak of it again.
More laughter. Mark lets it subside.
Question Two: "When you were stranded and alone up there... did you think you were gonna die?"
And there's a pause as Mark thinks about it. The rare mom of reflection for our hero.
He nods. Genuine:
Yes.
Then...

And it'll happen to you, too. You should know that going in. It's space. It's filled with chance, circumstance, and bad luck. It doesn't cooperate. At some point, I promise, at some point every single thing is gonna go south on you, and you'll think: this is it. This is how I end.
And you can either accept that... or you can get to work.
He lets those words land.
That's all it is. You simply begin. Solve one problem. Then the next one, then the next.
You solve enough problems... and you get to come home.
Mark opens his notebook.
All right. Questions?
Every hand in the class shoots into the air.
MUSIC UP: "LOVE TRAIN" by The O'Jays carries us to...
A SPACECRAFT is readied for launch.
...as soon as Mission Control finishes their pre-flight checks, we will begin launch procedures...
ANNIE MONTROSE stands at her place at the podium. Annie's little older, a little wiser, but can still command a roo

The Ares 5 team will rendezvous with the Hermes approximately 48 minutes after launch. From there, they've got 414 days of space travel ahead of them, arriving at Mars on March 30th. And I'll let the Director of Mars Missions, Vincent Kapoor, brief you on the particulars.
VINCENT steps to the podium. He's calm. At ease. Much better on television than we've ever seen him.
Good morning. Their mission is scheduled for 41 Sols. Your briefs detail the research and experiment schedules...
And the MUSIC CONTINUES THROUGHOUT as...
The room is ABUZZ WITH ACTIVITY as they prepare for launc
MINDY PARK takes her place at her STATION. She's moved up the world, now bears the title of:
Flight, CAPCOM. Ready to begin preflight check.
BRENDAN HATCH takes his place as the new FLIGHT DIRECTOR.
Go ahead, CAPCOM.
UP ABOVE: In the VIEWING ROOM... TEDDY SANDERS watches th activity from his solitary seat. He has his GREEN FOLDER the ready beside him.
A DEER trots through JPL grounds... it's still early yet the Jet Propulsion Labs in Pasadena....
But BRUCE NG is awake. And he still looks as exhausted an rumpled as ever. But he's in a good mood. He eats breakfa with his team outside as they watch the news reports detailing the "ARES 5 LAUNCH."
Bruce and his team laugh, make jokes with each other. One them tosses food to the deer.
"People all over the world, join in..."
Five BEAUTIFUL BLONDE CHILDREN race through the house, wearing NASA t-shirts and jumpsuits -- we get the sense t is the Superbowl for this family.
ALEX VOGEL grabs his youngest daughters as they race past He scoops them up in his arms. They laugh and laugh.
The Ares 5 astronauts secure themselves into their acceleration chairs. We settle on one astronaut:
WEN JIANG. The first Chinese national to go to Mars.
Guidance.
Go.
ZHU TAO and GUO MING stand at the back of the room, liste with pride as Wen runs through his check. A historic mome for their country.
MITCH HENDERSON watches his grandson run around the park. get the sense (the forced) retirement is treating him wel
"Let this train keep on riding, riding on through..."
CHRIS BECK accepts a bouquet of flowers from a nurse. Set them down next to the others as he checks on...
His wife. BETH JOHANSSEN. Who's holding THEIR NEWBORN BAB GIRL in her arms.
Beck climbs into the hospital bed next to them. 117.
As we hear the TIMER CONTROLLER initiate the COUNTDOWN...
We settle on the final member of the ARES 5 team:
RICK MARTINEZ. He grins as he feels that all-too-familiar surge of adrenaline. Here we go again...
We're MOVING DOWN THE HALLWAY of a quaint house. On the WALLS: vintage albums and posters...
Donna Summer's LAST DANCE on 7"... C'est Chic... A framed top that looks like something Gloria Gaynor wore...
And mixed in among the glittery paraphernalia:
The NASA Distinguished Service Medal... The Congressional Medal of Honor...
MELISSA LEWIS is glued to the television. She doesn't loo up as her husband brings her a cup of tea.
She's with the crew in this moment. Her husband doesn't t offense. He gives her a loving pat and exits.
"People all over the world, `round the world y'all, join hands..."
WIDE ON THE WHOLE ROOM as the team stares back at us in e anticipation.
Launch.
The crowd erupts into cheers. They reach for one another.
We drift up to find... 118.
Earth. Blue and beautiful.
Home.
